entries.text: You're welcome to attend this week's free London Perl and Raku Workshop 2025 on Saturday the 29th of November.
entries.title: You're invited: LPW 2025

entries.text: Talking about changes in the latest development release.
entries.title: This week in PSC (207) | 2025-11-17

entries.author: nathaniel_graham
entries.text: Just released Cron::Toolkit 0.09 to CPAN to help answer this and other puzzlers. Over 400 tests.
entries.title: When does February 29th next land on a Monday?

entries.author: dave_cross
entries.text: Dave continues to share his recent work with Google Cloud and Google Run.
entries.title: Elderly Camels in the Cloud

entries.author: mohammad_anwar
entries.text: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Power String" and "Meeting Point". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.
entries.title: The Weekly Challenge - 349

entries.author: mohammad_anwar
entries.text: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "String Alike" and "Convert Time" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.
entries.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 348

entries.author: ali
entries.text: This is professional-grade Perl code that demonstrates deep understanding of the language. The solutions are both correct and elegantly implemented.
entries.title: TWC348

entries.author: arne_sommer
entries.text: This is an excellent technical write-up and solid Raku code. Both scripts are idiomatic, correct, and easy to follow.
entries.title: Time Alike

entries.author: bob_lied
entries.text: The post is a clear, concise, and practical walkthrough of solving two weekly challenge problems. The code is functional, readable, and demonstrates a good understanding of Perl. The explanations are direct and easy to follow.
entries.title: String Alike, Convert Time

entries.author: jaldhar_vyas
entries.text: Jaldhar demonstrates good programming fundamentals and the ability to think critically about language design. The Perl context discussion alone makes this submission valuable, as it highlights a real learning barrier that affects many developers. The experienced-based commentary is exactly what helps improve programming languages and educational resources.
entries.title: Perl Weekly Challenge: Week 348

entries.author: jorg_sommrey
entries.text: Jorg demonstrates exceptional mathematical talent - the mixed radix solution to Task 2 is one of the most elegant I've seen for this problem. The J implementation is actually idiomatic and shows good understanding of array programming.
entries.title: The Times They Are a-Like

entries.author: luca_ferrari
entries.text: Excellent work! This showcases exceptional versatility in programming languages and database integration. The solutions are consistently correct across all implementations.
entries.title: splitting, counting and multiplying

entries.author: luis_mochan
entries.text: The combination of optimal algorithms, comprehensive error handling, and critical problem analysis places this submission in the top tier of challenge solutions. This is the quality of work one would expect from a senior software engineer.
entries.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 348

entries.author: matthias_muth
entries.text: This is professional-grade Perl programming that demonstrates both technical competence and thoughtful problem-solving. The solutions are not just correct but elegantly efficient.
entries.title: Get Those Strings and Times Covered

entries.author: packy_anderson
entries.text: This is an excellent and highly polished multi-language implementation. Packy demonstrates exceptional attention to detail, pedagogical clarity, and cross-language consistency.
entries.title: Ticking away the moments that make up a challengeâ€¦

entries.author: peter_campbell_smith
entries.text: This represents solid, practical Perl programming from someone with considerable experience. It demonstrates a focus on correctness, testing, and maintainability that is valuable in real-world programming.
entries.title: String time

entries.author: robbie_hatley
entries.text: This represents the work of an experienced software engineer who understands both the technical challenges and the importance of documentation. Excellent work that balances correctness, clarity, and practical considerations.
entries.title: The Weekly Challenge #348

entries.author: roger_bell_west
entries.text: This represents solid practical programming with good problem-solving skills. The mathematical approach to Task 2 is particularly commendable and shows Roger can think abstractly about problems.
entries.title: Time for Strings

entries.author: simon_green
entries.text: This is an excellent, well-explained, and pedagogically focused post. Simon demonstrates a strong grasp of Python fundamentals and a clear, methodical approach to problem-solving. The code is clean, correct, and accompanied by reasoning that is easy to follow.
entries.title: Alike Time

chapters.header: The Weekly Challenge by Mohammad Sajid Anwar will help you step out of your comfort-zone. You can even win prize money of $50 by participating in the weekly challenge. We pick one champion at the end of the month from among all of the contributors during the month, thanks to the sponsor Lance Wicks.
chapters.title: The Weekly Challenge

entries.title: Paris.pm monthly meeting

header: Just couple of days ago, we had another development release: Perl v5.43.5. Among the many changes in this release, my favourite is Named Parameters in Signatures. For further details, please check out the perldelta page.

The LPW 2025 is finally happening on 29th Nov 2025. So if you are available then please do join us for the tech meet. I would request you to register if you are planning to attend as this will help the organisers schedule the day accordingly. It's a great opportunity to meet friends and attend talks from speakers like Sawyer, Paul Evans and Stevan Little.

I have submitted a talk, Design Patterns in Modern Perl, and it has been accepted. I am excited to share my ideas with fellow tech friends. Here is the list of talks for you. One last thing, please register your favourite talks, this will help the organisers with scheduling. Someone also shared a very interesting post about Lunch options - LPW 2025.

The Advent Calendar is back and we need more articles for Perl Advent Calendar 2025. Please submit your proposal. I have proposed one about OpenAPI::Linter and it has already been accepted already. Soon, I'll submit the first draft. I know, time is running out - too many things to do in too little time.
Holiday season is kicking in, so take it easy and enjoy rest of the newsletter.
subject: Perl v5.43.5
